Brooklyn Historical Society
Brooklyn for Peace records
Brooklyn for Peace
Phillips, Charlotte
2016.026
25 Linear Feet in 39 manuscript boxes, 7 media boxes, 1 oversize flat box and 1 oversize flat file folder.
95 Cassettes
167 items (DVDs)
10 items (VHS)
7 items (CDs)
1983-2018 2002-2016 Brooklyn for Peace (BFP) was founded in 1984 as Brooklyn Parents for Peace by Charlotte Phillips and Carolyn Eisenberg, in response to the invasion of Granada by the United States. Through public events, publicity campaigns, lobbying of elected officials, and demonstrations, Brooklyn for Peace works to eliminate war and the social injustices that are its causes. BFP's records reveal both the history of the organization as well as the broader grassroots response to a wide variety of significant social and political issues at the local, regional and national levels from the late twentieth century to the present. Materials are in English.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Charlotte Phillips in 2016. A second accretion of material was delivered in 2018.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date (if known); Brooklyn for Peace records, 2016.026, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Conditions Governing Use
Copyright to this collection is retained by Brooklyn for Peace.
Processing Information
Paper materials were housed in archival folders and boxes. Materials were physcially grouped by subject, and duplicates were removed. All folder titles were supplied by the achivist, in consultation with Brooklyn for Peace. Scrapbook materials were removed from binders and plastic sleeves and placed in archival folders.
Please note that personal information, including email addresses, phone numbers and addresses are reducted throughout the collection. This was done by the donor prior to donation.
Appraisal
Duplicates of event flyers and routine correspondence were removed from the collection, as were newspaper and magazine clippings, receipts, blank forms, and other material not related to the interests and work of Brooklyn for Peace. Recordings of commerical broadcasts were removed from the collection.
Conditions Governing Access
The majority of this collection is open to research. A small portion of materials containing personally identifying information have been restricted, at the request of the donor, for a period of 30 years from the date of creation. Audiovisual material in this collection is not currently avaialble to researchers.
Scope and Contents
The Brooklyn for Peace records document the founding and ongoing activities of a Brooklyn-based community organization, Brooklyn for Peace (formerly Brooklyn Parents for Peace), covering the years 1984-2018. With over thirty years of work as a New York-based activist organization, BFP's institutional records reveal both the history of the organization as well as the grassroots response to a wide variety of significant social and political issues at the local, regional and national levels from the late twentieth century to the present. In particular, the records document BFP's organizational structure, key campaigns and projects, public events, and petitions circulated. These topics are represented through meeting minutes, mailings, internal correspondence, financial records, audio-visual material, and event ephemera including flyers, artwork and banners. The collection also includes substantial documentation of other local, regional and international organizations and individuals, through extensive subject files collected by BFP's leadership. Social and political issues that are particularly well represented in the collection include the campaign for nuclear disarmament, anti-war organizing from the Gulf War through the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and the Israel-Palestine conflict.
Biographical / Historical
Brooklyn for Peace (BFP) was founded in 1984 as Brooklyn Parents for Peace by Charlotte Phillips and Carolyn Eisenberg, in response to the invasion of Grenada by the United States. Since then, through public events, publicity campaigns, lobbying of elected officials, and demonstrations, Brooklyn for Peace has worked to eliminate war and the social injustices that are its causes. The organization works on domestic and international issues in an attempt to create a peaceful future. BFP operates as a membership-based, democratic, non-partisan, 501(c)3 corporation run by a Board of Directors.
Over the course of thirty years, BFP has worked on a wide range of issues pertaining to local, regional and international peace issues. BFP's committees have included: Arts and Culture, Anti-militarism (counter-recruitment), Climate Action, Darfur/Africa, Diversity and Outreach, Fundraising, International Law, Israel-Palestine, Latin America, Nuclear Zero, Peace and Economic Justice, Peace Fair, and UNICEF. There are several affiliated neighborhood-focused peace groups in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Bay Ridge, Flatbush, Fort Greene, and Prospect-Lefferts Gardens. Regular efforts of BFP include organizing community meetings and forums, staffing information tables at relevant community and regional events, participating in phone and advertising campaigns, lobbying elected officials, participating in demonstrations, and providing didactic materials pertaining to targeted areas that fall within the mission of the organization.
BFP's earliest projects included organizing local opposition to a proposed Staten Island port for nuclear-capable cruise missiles, as well as protesting U.S. interventions in Central America and the 1991 Gulf War. Following September 11th, BFP advocated for the protection of civil liberties and opposed the detention of immigrants. In response to the No Child Left Behind Act in 2001, BFP sought to limit military recruiting in New York City public schools. This included distributing leaflets such as "How to Go to College Without Joining the Military."
BFP has organized against the wars in Iraq, Iran, Syria, Yemen, and Afghanistan, against police brutality in New York City, and for a peaceful solution to the Israel-Palestine conflict. More recently, BFP has activated public engagement against fracking, the Rockaway Pipeline, and a Liquefied Natural Gas port on Long Island. From 2003 until 2015 BFP hosted a regular Peace and Justice Fair. The Peace Fair included musical and theater performances, educational forums and discussions, and was primarily intended as an outreach forum. Additionally, since 2006 BFP has hosted a monthly program "War No More" on BRIC's Brooklyn Community Access TV station.
Arrangement
This collection has been arranged into five series:
Series 1: Administration, 1985-2018
Series 2: Scrapbooks, 2003-2016
Series 3: Events, 1988-2017
Series 4: War No More Program, 2006-2012
Series 5: Subject Files, 1986-2017
Series 6: Petitions, 1985-2015

Series 1: Adminstration5 Linear Feetin 12 manuscript boxes and 1 oversize folder.1985-2018
Scope and Contents
This series contains materials pertaining to the administration of Brooklyn for Peace from its founding in 1984 until the present. This includes correspondence and minutes of the Executive Board, committee correspondence and project files, and financial records and fundraising endeavors. Records from the Israel-Palestine Committee are particularly well represented. This series also includes general administrative records including correspondence regarding event endorsements, membership lists and special events, as well as office materials including organizational appointment books and notebooks. Finally, this series includes administrative records pertaining to the organization of the annual Peace and Justice Fair.

Scope and Contents
Compiled by BFP leadership, this series includes 20 dated volumes of material representing the work of the organization, including events, meetings, discussions, interests, and conflicts. Material in this series consists primarily of event ephemera, newspaper clippings, informational pamphlets, correspondence, Brooklyn-based publications, and a small amount of administrative records. Volumes are organized by time period and cover BFP's involvement in the community throughout their existence, with a focus on the years 2003 through 2011. This series offers an overview of what BFP was doing in the community, what interested them as an organization, and what BFP's leadership felt was important to represent and document as an organization.
Arrangement
Material in this series has been arranged chronologically.Prior to 20031971-2002111Volume 11987-2002112-3Volume 22003114-5Volume 32003116-7Volume 42004118-9Volume 520041110Volume 52004121Volume 72005122-3Volume 82005124-5Volume 92005126-8Volume 102006129Volume 102006131-2Volume 112006133-6Volume 122006-2007137-8Volume 122006-2007141Volume 132007142-5Volume 142007-2008146-7Volume 142007-2008151-2Volume 152008153-6Volume 162008-2009157Volume 162008-2009161-3Volume 172009164-7Volume 182010171-4Volume 192011175-7Series 3: Events4.48 Linear Feetin 1 and a half manuscript boxes, 7 media boxes and 1 oversize folder.1988-2017
Scope and Contents
This series includes materials and recordings from events that BFP organized from their founding through 2018, addressing local, national, and international topics and conflicts. Ephemeral material in this series consists primarily of publicity mailings, event announcements and invitations, informational leaflets, program pamphlets, community outreach material, program and event descriptions and signs, as well as lobbying and propaganda material. Event recordings include cassettes, CD, VHS and DVD recordings of panel discussions, protests, and the Brooklyn Peace Fair. Subjects that are well represented are the Israel-Palestine conflict, the role of money in politics, local and national climate policy, and nuclear disarmament. Topics ranged from the local level, with interests such as the effort to shut down Indian Point, to international concerns in South Africa, Japan, Latin America, and the Middle East.
Arrangement
Ephemera has been grouped by subject and arranged alphabetically. Scope and Contents
War No More is a monthly television program produced by Brooklyn for Peace, and screened on the public access network Brooklyn Free Speech (BRIC channel 2). The show has aired since 2006, and includes interviews, event recordings and in-depth discussions of local, national and international political issues.
Arrangement

Scope and Contents
This series includes material from a wide range of political organizations and individuals at the local, regional, national and international levels working on issues of interest to BFP. Material in this series consists primarily of publicity mailings and event ephemera, although there is a small amount of correspondence. Subjects that are well represented in this series include BFP's core issues of anti-war and militarism, nuclear disarmament, and the Israel-Palestine conflict. Other topics include racial justice in New York City, abolition, police brutality, and the conflict in Darfur, Sudan.

Scope and Contents
Material in this series consists of petitions signed and turned in to BFP to support their efforts to bring an end to local and international war and conflicts. These petitions contain biographical information including names, addresses, and phone numbers of the signees. Subjects that are well represented in this series include the War in Iraq, the Israel-Palestine conflict, biased New York Police Department practices, and a Nuclear-free New York City
Arrangement
Materials have been grouped by subject and are arranged alphabetically.Abolition 2000 - Missiles to Sunflowers20003114
